Award.AwardTitle: Comparative genome-scale analyses of submergence and anaerobic germination mechanisms in rice and maize
Award.AbstractNarration: Flooding events significantly damage agricultural production in the US and elsewhere. The development of crop cultivars that can survive short-term flooding can help stabilize and increase food production. The recent recognition of rice varieties tolerant to short-term flooding has led to the identification of the submergence tolerance regulator gene called SUB1A. The precise genetic characterization of SUB1A has allowed breeders to develop new high-yielding rice varieties with submergence tolerance that are now grown in flood-prone fields of South and Southeast Asia. This project will continue the molecular characterization of SUB1A and seek new submergence regulators that act earlier in development. Rice plants that can survive flooding during seed germination can reduce labor cost and herbicide use. The effectiveness of combining SUB1A with the recently identified ANAEROBIC GERMINATION 1 (AG1) gene will be explored in rice. Additionally, the characterization of molecular responses to flooding will be extended to corn, a vital grain crop that is flooding sensitive. These analyses will examine genetic variation in anaerobic germination and submergence tolerance in maize as well as profile and manipulate molecular responses to these stresses. The results will provide a greater understanding of sensing, signaling and response mechanisms to flooding during seed germination and vegetative growth in rice and maize. The research will be carried out at a Hispanic Serving institution. Postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate researchers will receive cross-disciplinary training in physiology, molecular biology, analytical chemistry and systems biology in a multicultural laboratory and institute environment. The development and dissemination of a science-learning module will allow 8th graders, many from underrepresented groups, at Title I schools to participate in hands-on science experiments demonstrating the significance of plant biology research on food security and sustainable agriculture. The knowledge obtained from this project will favorably impact food, feed and fuel production in the US and elsewhere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Floods cause significant damage to agricultural production in the US and elsewhere in the world. The development of crop cultivars that can survive short-term flooding events can alleviate the shortfall in crop yields, which is necessary for food security in the 21st century. Genes in existing crop varieties or crop relatives that aid survival of floods can feasibly be identified using modern molecular genetic technologies and then transferred by breeding into established cultivars in order to improve consistency in crop yields.

This project studied the SUBMERGENCE 1A (SUB1A) gene that enables rice (Oryza sativa) plants to endure a period of two weeks or longer of complete submergence. Prior to the start of this project, the SUB1A gene was identified from an Indian rice variety and transferred though traditional breeding to more than 10 modern varieties to help stabilize losses in production associated with floods. These ‘Sub1’ varieties are now grown in many flood susceptible areas in South and Southeast Asia. In light of the wide adoption of this rice, the major goal of this project was to increase the understanding of the molecular function of SUB1A and to seek knowledge of its interaction with other flooding tolerance regulators. The project also sought to understand why corn is highly flooding sensitive.

There were three major achievements. (1) We characterized a naturally occurring rice gene, ANEROBIC GERMINATION1 (AG1), which aids flooding tolerance as seeds germinate. International collaborators identified AG1, and we elucidated the manner in which it manifests rapid underwater shoot growth. Experiments were also carried out to evaluate the interaction between SUB1A-1 and AG1, as varieties that combine both tolerances could allow farmers to directly seed rice that would be able to survive later floods. These studies were augmented by the development of methods and execution of experiments by analytical chemists that provided information on the remodeling of cell metabolism during anaerobic germination and flooding that are controlled by SUB1A and AG1. (2) We performed comparative studies to evaluate submergence tolerance and anaerobic germination capacity of corn (Zea mays), a vital grain crop that is highly sensitive to floods. This included an examination of genetic variation within the parental lines of modern corn varieties that found little evidence of intrinsic tolerance of submergence. By contrast, variation was found in the capacity of corn seeds to germinate under oxygen-starved conditions that can occur due to soil compaction or heavy rains after planting. To understand the molecular deficiency of corn in flooded environments, transcriptional and translation regulation of genes in response to submergence and anaerobic germination were profiled and compared to rice and the model plant Arabidopsis. (3) We studied the molecular function of a family of gene activators (transcription factors), of which SUB1A was the first member to be characterized, in rice, maize and the model plant Arabidopsis. The results provide new understanding of an evolutionarily conserved family of regulators that control gene activity when cells have insufficient oxygen (hypoxia) and plants are flooded.

Results from this project are included in 17 peer-reviewed publications, two PhD dissertations, and one MS dissertation. The project trained two postdoctoral scholars, eight graduate students, eight undergraduate students, and one high school student.
